data.title: clarksonhistory
data.meta_description: Posts about 1920s written by Glenn Čada
data.text:
Back to our Village’s beer history, but first a few definitions. One of my smartest readers noted that I was throwing around the terms saloon, tavern, and bar loosely, and she wondered whether there were differences among them? After doing … Continue reading →

One of the sturdiest buildings on Our Village’s main street is situated on the northeast corner of 3rd and Pine Streets (the gray, concrete block structure on the right side of the above photo). The building, which has stood on … Continue reading →

I have received another batch of old photographs from Sharon Odvarka Steinberger, who was kind enough to let me look them over before passing them on to the Clarkson Museum. Most of them came from the collection of the Odvarka … Continue reading →

One of my earliest memories of my Grandmother Antonia Polodna was a time when she set me on her lap and told me a story about my grandfather, the Steam Engineer. He was a lifelong farmer, but when he was … Continue reading →

In the liturgical calendar of the Roman Catholic Church, today is the Holy Trinity Sunday. It is the day set aside to celebrate one of the most profound and mysterious Christian beliefs – that God is three persons in one … Continue reading →

Memorial Day has always been a special holiday in our town. The last Monday in May had been set aside to honor the soldiers who had died in the service of our country. Formal services at the Clarkson Cemetery were … Continue reading →

I call the mystery photos above “The Destruction of Karel and Suchy.” They depict the August 13, 1967 demolition of a building that had stood on Clarkson’s main street since about 1892. In its first decade, the wooden building housed a … Continue reading →

It’s time for another fun quiz. These two pictures were taken on August 13, 1967. Who can tell me what is happening here? The more you tell me about the building, how it was used over the years, etc. then … Continue reading →

Not everyone from Clarkson who fought in World War I was under the command of Gen. John J. Pershing and the American Expeditionary Forces. At least one of our local boys, Jaroslav Holas, went overseas to fight the Central Powers … Continue reading →

On a recent autumn night I was driving down a quiet stretch of highway between North Bend and Snyder, when I came over a rise and encountered a coyote trotting across the road. Neither of us had time to avoid … Continue reading →
